pros: Working with bright engaging students

pros: The benefits (medical, PTO, retirement) are very, very good. Recently the University has been more flexible with allowing remote work for employees who do not have forward facing positions, i.e. those whose work is done behind a computer screen and have little to no face to face interactions in order to effectively do their job are given some flexibility to work remotely. It should be noted that this depends on ones department, supervisor, and performance. This is a huge benefit and I sincerely hope the University continues to allow this flexibility for it's employees. There are opportunities to move around within the University if you are interested in doing so. There are many job opportunities here and often times, supervisors are supportive of internal movement to other positions.
cons: It is very difficult to receive merit based salary increases, so it is very important to negotiate a salary you are very comfortable with before you accept your position. Unless you receive the opportunity to significantly increase your responsibilities in your current position, or change your position entirely, it has proved difficult to negotiate any increase outside of state/union-wide increases, which have been around half a percentage point over the past few years (>0.5%). Unfortunately, this inability to provide even moderate raises for performing well (again, outside of state/union allocations) or giving consideration for cost of living increases, can be very discouraging if you hope to increase your income while remaining in the same position for any length of time. However, as mentioned in the pros, the benefits are excellent and help to slightly off-set this potential downside.

review_title: Protect the senior staffs above morality
pros: - Pay was ok - Some coworkers were nice
cons:
- Culture of silence. Several instances of harassment happen to me during the time I worked there. I did not say anything until these escalated into interfering with my performance as a student. When I said something the response from supervisors was just overall total invalidation of my claims. The person behind the harassment was defended because they were more senior and my supervisor got very defensive to the point where they would not even let me speak, talking over me the whole time to control the narrative. Very toxic behavior. 
- Lack of morals. Acts of immorality are committed and before you know it, they are blaming you for them when you have nothing to do with it. 
 - Throw you into a LOT of responsibilities without training - Hypocrisy. At my worst moments working at this University I just kept asking myself: Is the mission of this institution to support students? really? Some people here seem more interested into advancing their own careers than supporting the students that get to work with them.

review_title: Undergraduate- Psychology Major and Forensic Health Minor
pros: I have a passion for mental health awareness and psychology. I strive to take advantage of my education, as one of the nation's elite public universities, Binghamton combines rigorous academics, distinguished faculty, and state-of-the-art facilities to engage and challenge me.
cons: It's very cold and I hope to work somewhere warmer than upstate new york in the future.

job_title: Assistant Director of Graduate Operations in Binghamton, NY
pros: The gym is nice and staff get a discounted membership. State employee health benefits almost make it worth putting up with.
cons: There are some phenomenal people working at Binghamton U. And they are all leaving because the administration here is run by faculty members who have been promoted to leadership positions and have no actual idea of what it takes to run an administrative office or support staff members. Staff are hired into SL levels and can be transferred, against their will, to any position on campus as long as it is in the same SL level. I was “reassigned” from admissions, where I had 5 years of experience, to operations, where I was put in charge of the Graduate School’s giant budget. I had no experience with budgets on this scale and I didn’t apply for this posting when it became available because I wasn’t interested or qualified. HR wouldn’t do anything and neither would the union. I applied for other jobs on campus that I was qualified for within academic affairs but all of these supervisors rolled up to Provost Nieman and I wasn’t able to move within the campus community. So I left Binghamton University as soon as I secured a better position. Which was incredibly disappointing because Binghamton had become my home - I graduated there twice, I met my husband there, all of our friends were in the area. But the internal politics and bureaucracy were unbearable. That’s not even considering the bullying inside the Graduate School office where I was yelled at by a coworker, in front of our boss, that I wasn’t even wanted there as an employee so I could just leave. The supervisor did nothing and the coworker, who has a reputation for being extremely difficult to work with, continued to create a hostile environment that I was hesitant to report due to fear of retaliation. I was in a situation set up to fail and couldn’t leave fast enough! Would not recommend working as a staff person here.

review_title: Small SUNY in a Red Small City
pros:
Small campus. Can move around easily.
Intimate. Can know a lot of people from a lot of different departments easily.
Strong Science Programs. SUNY has a reputation for some of its programs.
Nature Preserve is nearby
Cohesive work community
cons:
Locals that constitute vendors and construction openly hate non-whites and "libs"
Women make much less than men in all departments
Unions are powerless and maintain status quo. Summer BBQ? Union's got you. Issue with department? Union is nowhere to be found.
University lacks funds to make responsible COVID decisions. 
Faculty have the local red-district state of mind - COVID is over! no big deal! 
Remote work adverse. Even if you can feasibly work from a computer all day, you have to find parking on campus, go to your office, and sit in the office and work. You are not allowed to work remotely, period.
Human resources is impossible to get a hold of, especially when your paycheck didn't show up or if your doctor can't process your health insurance because it dropped out of the blue
Salaries are far below even the region's averages across the board- professors, grad students, custodians, assistants, you name it
The only public university I've worked at where employees can't get tuition reduced if they want to take a class. I've tried all of the forms, paperwork, you name it, and no one has any idea how to make the tuition benefit happen. It doesn't actually exist.

review_title: Great place to work with benefits

cons: The pay could be higher and the university could provide some educational benefits to the families of workers.

pros: Very helpful support staff, department secretaries are very nice.
cons: University is not prestigious enough to get very good experience, I found that the department was of lackluster talent. Faculty only tries to get R01 grants every 5 years and wait until funding is over which is not sustainable, as many labs are close to being shut down or borrowing funds from others to do research. Also, the number of hours you need to put in as a post-doctoral researcher to be given mediocrre advice at best is laughable. You can spend all your time assisting with publications and grants yet when it comes to your career, the faculty could care less. They simply use post-docs to go up the ranks of professor. Professors do not care about students and those in the early stages of their career. I was one of the best post-docs in the department for number of publications and throughput yet it left me completely unwilling to continue in research due to the people.

review_title: Not a nice climate inside or out
pros:
There is food available in the student union that cam be purchased by anyone.
There is any kind of fast food chain you can imagine right around the univrsity
cons: It is a cold climate both inside and out. Read some of the recent reports and take them seriously. If anything they under estimate the problems. I've seen tons of money spent to recruit senior hires and then seen them bashed once on campus. One department spent oodles of money readying labs for the new senior hires . Then they treated them so badly the new hires left before the new construction was finish. I'm not sure if it was their intent or not but once they left, the existing faculty who had started their careers at Binghamton had the space and resources assigned to themselves. I guess there is some payoff for being terrible to new hires. This may not be wide spread. it might only be true in the sciences. Ask about the interpersonal climate of the department if you are thinking of taking a job here or being a graduate student. If a grad student, ask how long it takes to get the degree.

review_title: Great university to work at, great faculty, brilliant students
pros: Binghamton University is a bright intellectual spot in the middle of nowhere.  While it is a small university, it is a thriving New York State research center with amazing leadership and the cream of the crop of students.  As New York State employees, we get great healthcare and retirement packages.  And the cost of living and housing prices here quite good, and it's great to live in a beautiful, green, hilly part of the country.
cons: All assistant professors start at the same base salary.  If you're a fresh 30-year-old PhD with no prior experience, the pay is excellent and competitive with industry.  If you have an extra decade or so of prior experience, the pay is poor, because you can get double that much in industry.  Also, being in a small town, it's hard to find things to do without driving a long distance; for instance, the nearest good mall is 1.5 hours away in Syracuse.

pros: As a student also attending the University, its a great place to work because it is convenient as well as flexible with course schedule. In addition, there is a lot of knowledge about the University and opportunities available to be learned through working there.
cons: The largest downside of working at a campus job while in school is the pay, which most often starts at minimum wage. In addition, because it is a State school, employment is through NYS which is slow in regards to paycheck delays.

review_title: It was better than minimum wage
pros: It is great to have union benefits. Sick time and vacation are really charitable. Salaries are really decent (though not in comparison to the workload).
cons: Extremely overworked employees, zero support from above, administrative leaders push forward plans without thinking about their impact so entry level professionals suffer consequences. Don’t pay for extra work assigned. Terrible at diversity and inclusion. If you are a part of any minority group run far away.

pros: Some flexibility in hours and the benefits are very good. The best thing has been interfacing with students about topics both parties care about - discussions on the subject matter, of course, but also the tangents and what young people are interested, worried, and thinking about.
cons: Parking. While part-timers are welcome and necessary for the proper functioning of the university, unfortunately the meetings and opportunities offered are definitely in favor of those that work 10am-4pm.

review_title: Fun learning experience and a solid on campus job
pros: The work is interesting and easy for anyone to learn how to do.  The work is technical and you get to learn technical skills while getting paid.  You also get to set your own hours, which helps maintain schoolwork while holding the job.  You also get to meet many new people as well.
cons: The work is inconsistent, and since the job is by the hour, the pay is inconsistent.  Really is not a job that someone should try to live off of, but I feel that is obvious.

review_title: Valuable job experience for student employees
pros: I really enjoyed working with the people from Binghamton University.  They always looked out for me while I was a student employee, and afterwards they have given me guidance and advice.  Many of the positions involve creating excellent, resume and portfolio-building content.
cons: While the campus and immediate vicinity is beautiful, the nearby city of Binghamton is hardly the greatest place on earth.

job_title: Residential Life Staff in Binghamton, NY
pros: Great for power hungry folks. Possibly a good stepping stone for those interested in working here over a period of less than or equal to 2 years. If you're staying longer than that in the same position here, you are most likely stuck in life.
cons: Generally, the professional staffs will not speak up when needed and will save themselves before thinking twice about the students' needs. The pro staff will try to display residential life at Binghamton University as caring, loving, and respectful. None of that is what goes on in residential life.  And because of all that residential life doesn't do or own up to, there's a high turnover rate of professional staff positions in residential life.  Approved 8/15/19

pros: Smart students, health benefits, decent stipend
cons: Deceptive practices, far too much work for graduate teaching assistants, assignment varies from semester to semester depending on department need and professor you are working with

pros: PODS consultant job at Binghamton University is just great. For the most of the time, it is not an intensive job and it is possible to study and work at the same time. Helping students out make me feel good, and it is also a great place to exercise the customer service, helping customers solving problems, trying to being nice and know how to make them happy!
cons: Many will get only 10-12 hours a week to work because there are so many of PODS consultants need jobs. Except this, everything is great.

pros: Binghamton University provides an enriching educational experience for all it’s students and will continue to fo so in years to come thank to efforts to expand its own resources in the coming years.
cons: Certain departments can be improved upon, especially with regards to reputation. It will come as no surprise that this will be the major source of scrutiny for Binghamton in the coming years.

pros: very good facilities with cutting edge technology. Lot of green around the buildings. Great place to learn new things and gain some experience with the engineering equipment.
cons:
Shortage of funding.  not too many companies around the place. Difficult to find a job.
Campus job fair is just good for advertising about the University. Very very few people(out of hundreds) landed with a job through campus job fair.

review_title: Binghamton was great in so many ways; I thoroughly enjoyed my time there.
job_title: Administrative Assistant to the Director in Binghamton, NY
pros: There were a lot of smart people who care about good work. I was always impressed by the people around me.
cons: Binghamton the town can be sad. There is a lot of blight and things that are run down. It has a lot of social and economic issues that make it less desirable of a place to live.

pros: Some really good students. Accommodating professors. Real teaching experience in front of a classroom. Excellent chance to hone public speaking, presentation and teaching skills. I highly enjoyed teaching and got excellent reviews from my students on my classes. I often would work extra office hours or host review sessions before exams. Also experience grading exams and homework
cons: Teaching is hardwork and going to the lectures is often repetitive and time consuming. Also no incentive to TA more than 1 semester

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This university provides an excellent learning environment in which students can truly focus and commit to their studies. I would recommend attending this university.
cons: The biggest con regarding Binghamton university is the location of the university. Binghamton University is located in the City of  Binghamton. The city of Binghamton unfortunately is a low-income city with many violent neighborhoods.

pros: Super flexible hours to fit within your classes. Really great environment with a bunch of college students who you'll love to be working with. Everybody who works here is kind and inviting.
cons: Obviously there is not much room for advancement at a university gym. Opening hours are early and closing hours are late due to the gym always being open.

review_title: Not yet looking forward to join the team

Because it's awesome university
Its rank as five stars in my opinion
Also,I saw many good benefits and prestigious jobs in it which I really think it's a great fit to me
cons: New to country but now I'm a BCC student and I started mingling a lot in society with different cultures

review_title: Good university in the middle of nowhere.
pros: It is a large research university. Students are relatively good. Colleagues are interested in research.
cons: There is no culture outside of university. Binghamton is a city of poor people. The closest place with culture is Ithaca: 1 hour drive in good weather. NYC is 3.5 hours away. Housing is not expensive but mostly old.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Good part-time opportunities for students everywhere. I worked for the Campus Activities Department on campus, and also worked for the Binghamton University Libraries. Both experiences were very good.
cons: There weren't too many in the roles I worked for; the full-time staff treated student workers just fine. Depending on your job, there can be some downtime.

pros: Nice environment. great group of people who I work with. small group, so people cooperate with each other and also care about each other
cons: don't have any cons at this point, the pay is good, and I really enjoy the working content as well. probably the only con will be that the school should hire more people who learn different languages because we have all kinds of books but librarians have very limited knowledge in  languages sometimes make the work difficult

pros: Graduate teaching assistantships are a great way to gain experience and skills.  They can help you decide if you want to be a teacher in your particlar area or help prepare you for a wider variety of jobs in yoru field.
cons: Poor opportunities for funding in my particular graduate program and poor pay and benefits for students who do get funding.

pros:
Binghamton University is young and growing.
The new President has a vision and people are getting on board. 
It is exciting to see where the University is headed, and being a part of it.
They offer a competitive salary, and NYS State benefits are still good if you are a state worker.
cons: There is a huge bureaucratic, politicized environment that can be sometimes tough to break through. It is changing as the organization is aligned to the President's vision, though.

job_title: Operations Facilities Graduate Assistant in Binghamton, NY
pros: Relaxed atmosphere and lots of good communication between the professional staff and students.  People generally seem to have a good time while they are at work.
cons: Some student employees do not care about their jobs which makes everyone else more difficult.  Some students are also bad about calling in prior to missing shifts.

job_title: Graduate and Teaching Assistant in Binghamton, NY
pros: Different experiences can be learned, work across different environments including healthcare, management, and education. Solve complex problems related to quality, operations, etc.
cons: An employee needs to work longer that what would be expected to complete the tasks assigned to him/her. Also no real research advising.

pros: Amazing Business school.  Some really great professors bring the real world in to the classroom - overall they prepare you for the real world. Great job at bringing employers to the students especially in Accounting
cons: Some assignments are seen as busy work.  Tests are usually harder than classwork and assignments. Test banks dominate curve on tests.

review_title: Good Job for a Student during the School Year or Summer
pros:
- As a lifeguard during the summer term, the pool was usually quite empty and the atmosphere was laid back
  - As a reserve lifeguard during the year, I got to help out other guards when they needed someone to cover them
 - Discounted gym membership
cons: None I can think of. It was a good gig for summer with flexibility during the school year as a reserve lifeguard.

pros: Flexible hours, nice environment to work in. Refereeing intramural games is an exciting and relaxing job, would recommend working here part time.
cons: There are sometimes shifts that involve late hours, and when there are conflicts in schedule you may have trouble finding people to cover your shifts if you need off.

pros: We have a very creative Calculus department. We introduced flipped teaching method and the students will watch the videos before they enter the class.
cons: Sometimes students complain that there are too much material cover in one semester and they want the calculus 2 to be extended to 2 semesters.

job_title: Campus Life Graduate Coordinator in Vestal, NY
pros: The campus is a nice size and you get to know the people within the departments well, and it is a nice environment.
cons: The campus can feel a little cold sometimes, figuratively, and a little segregated, but you just need to find your cluster of close friends.

pros: Supervisors are graduate students who are friendly and give great advice. Always willing to help and answer questions.
cons: Difficult to gain experience. Little to no interaction with the lab director. Too much reading of articles and not enough hands on experience.

pros: Flexible with time off & personal life. People who work there are friendly and social and can be fun. It all depends on where you work.
cons: School of Management needs help with managing their people. Other areas have lots of politics and lots of bureaucracy. Not fun

review_title: Working for the Physics Department as a Graduate Assistant
pros: The department staff is extremely friendly and helpful. They all know that the work has to be done, but they try to make the process fun.
cons: There is no schedule of when the labs are in use by classes so it is hard to find a good time to do lab testing without interrupting them.

review_title: Difficult past but maybe hope for the future
pros: A new administration may help correct the horrid abuses of the past. The "Kaye Report" and finally responding to all the complaints about hazing, both of which revealed the extent to which the previous administration denied wrong doings that later became obvious and public, may have helped to speed the change in administration. There is hope that the new administration may turn things around and make the university a better place for students, faculty and staff.
cons: A long history of those in powerful positions and those with grants being able to do anything they want with no fear of consequences even when people's lives and careers were at stake, made the university a very difficult place to work. Many staff and faculty members felt marginalized.  The previous university administration went beyond simply allowing wrong doing but participated in it-some that was later documented in the Kay Report. If you want a partial history, google "The Kaye Report" and be astounded by the conduct described. Now consider that what the report describes as conduct in one department was going on across the entire campus in different ways depending upon the department and circumstances. Those that complained were harmed further. Those who filed grievances were denied due process. It was a systemic problem-top down. It was horrible for those that tried to follow ethical guidelines, for those with a moral compass and for those who complained or filed grievances. But, there was pretty much a clean sweep of the administration so things may may be looking up. If you are considering a job on campus, ask the hard questions. What is the morale? How do those at the top and bottom feel about the department, school or office. Ask to talk with those who are noticeably absent from your interview schedule. In the past, those unhappy were marginalized and described in harmful ways in an attempt to devalue and degrade what they had to say. Be aware of that past and dig beneath the surface. Hopefully by the time you are interested in a job there, things will have improved appreciably.

pros: work with students and people who are really helpful. you work with people your age mostly
cons: not much training goes on, and there is not much room for growth within the work place. When it comes to favors they don't really do much

pros: one of the best public university and being a TA give you scholarship and also gain a good experience on teaching

pros:

review_title: wonderful experience working as a grad assistant

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Binghamton, NY

cons: There are many new responsibilities to juggle as a graduate student, and it takes a while to adjust to simultaneously teaching and learning.

review_title: It's a decent place to work

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY

cons: i can't really thing of a cons. I was pretty happy with it

pros: Good pay vs workload. Good with time off when my wife was in labor.
